story:
The Town Tart is an old fashioned lunch counter and pie shop in Hamden, Connecticut. 

Owner, Val McKee, is taking her popular home kitchen pie business to a larger audience and adding more to the menu, but she needs your help! Val is transforming a neighborhood clock shop into a restaurant, which means there is much work to be done. Aside from the usual upgrades to the space, there must be a complete renovation to build a commercial kitchen, restrooms, countertops (you can't have a proper lunch counter without one!), booths (for those who prefer not to sit shoulder to shoulder), coffee and ice cream bar, and much, much more! 

Val could have rented a space already equipped with a kitchen, but location was extremely important to her. She wanted to open The Town Tart in a walkable, family friendly neighborhood; a place where people can come on their lunch breaks, children can come after school, and families can come on the weekends. See, Val lives in Spring Glen neighborhood in Hamden, Connecticut. Her three boys attend Spring Glen Elementary. She knew this neighborhood needed a spot like The Town Tart, as it's lacking a cozy lunch spot and place for community to gather. She knew she could provide a place for neighborhood residents and beyond to come and cozy up with the greatest comfort food of all: PIE! 

We want all guests of The Town Tart to arrive feeling welcome and comfortable and leave with full, satisfied bellies. We want families to build food memories while sitting at our counter. We want customers to find joy in the modern take on traditional Southern fare, from pimento cheese sandwiches to Val's favorite lemon meringue pie on a gingersnap crust. 

We hope you will consider helping Val make this dream a reality! Please consider making a donation to help The Town Tart open its doors.

 

 

*The Town Tart will serve lunch from 11:00am-3:00pm. Pie, coffee, and ice cream floats from 10:00am - 8:00pm.*

 

---About Val---

Val McKee is a native Tennessean who set roots in Connecticut in 2004. She is a writer, musician, and teacher of both, but the joy of her life is being mom to her three sons.
Val has many interests in life, but watching someone take a bite of a pie she has baked tops the fun list.

Her greatest hope is for someone to take a bite of apple pie, twenty years from now, and say something like: "This reminds me of that pie we had at The Town Tart...remember? When the kids were little and we stopped for lunch after spending the morning at the park." She wants to help people build the same lovely food memories she made with her grandfather.

Val owes her sweet tooth to her grandfather, who loved coconut cake, always had fig newtons in the cupboard, and had a secret candy drawer in his office. When her mother told him his grandchildren could only have candy once a week, he'd arrive at the door on Saturday morning with a bag full of his favorites. We called it Saturday morning candy. When Val left home for school, her grandfather would write every week and include a single piece of Big Red gum in the envelope.

Her grandfather  was a business owner in her small hometown and Val hopes to make her customers feel even a smidgen of the love he gave to each and every person who walked through his business's doors. She hopes to make every Town Tart customer feel like they are sitting at her dining room table when they take a seat in this new space; whether they dig into a piece of her pie, bite into a sandwich, or take a sip of an artisanal ice cream float.

This shop is inspired by and dedicated to you, Nana.

story:
We seek funds to support the construction of a thatch roof for our center, as well as funds for a solar pump to draw nearby water to the center...

THE CEREMONIAL, ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL CENTER CCEC HUACHI WIRIKUTA HUACHICHIZTLAN emerged in the community of San Antonio de Coronados, (El Paraje del Coyote). Since 1987, the organization Kalpulli Ameyaltonal (Health, Culture and Tradition), has enabled uninterrupted presentation of the Aztec Chichimeca dance and has supported the community with rites and ceremonies. Using traditional herbal and Mexican medicine, a relationship of friendship and common support became established among the inhabitants of the community and the members of Ameyaltonal. Leaders, David Mazat and Marucha Ilhuikatzin, who accompanied by their family and dance group, maintain the indigenous traditions of the Anahuac, and have planted in the community a ceremonial space and center, with an ecological-environmental consciousness, of culture and traditional medicine of the Anahuac.  

We risk losing visitors and a bond amongst distant relatives but we are overcoming obstacles via the internet which provides amble connection. We support academic trips that include researching herbal plants, providing astronomy classes as well as bridging a gap amongst brothers and sisters. 

Please share this campaign with your networks both north and south of the border.

story:
Who We Are

We are Bill Bowman and PJ Parker, co-publishers of The Franklin Reporter & Advocate, Franklin Township’s only local, online news site. Nobody covers Franklin Township the way we do, period.

We have decades of experience in community journalism and are long-time residents of Franklin Township. We know how important it is to our neighbors to have a reliable source of information for what’s going on in their township.

The Franklin Reporter & Advocate covers everything about our township, from what’s happening in the hallways of our schools to what’s being decided in the hallways of power. We think of ourselves as having the sensibility of a traditional weekly newspaper with the immediacy of the Internet.

We know through experience that the so-called legacy media – the large newspaper chains – are in a freefall right now. They’re panicking because they see their once-healthy profit margins shrinking, and they’re not sure how to deal with that new normal. As a result, the choices they’ve made over the last six or seven years have been drastic and have caused a severe reduction in the amount of local coverage being afforded towns and communities.

In Franklin Township, that’s where the Franklin Reporter & Advocate comes in to play. 

The Franklin Reporter & Advocate covers Franklin Township like a blanket, and our readers – and our community – appreciate that. Now we need to take the next step in our evolution.

What We Need & What You Get

There has not been a local news outlet in Franklin Township for many years; we are bridging that information gap. But not everyone in the township has heard of us yet. We are seeking to raise a minimum of $30,000 to fund a major town-wide saturation marketing program to increase the awareness of our news site throughout the community, so that everyone in the township will know that they once again have a source for local news. 

The money we raise will be used to hire a marketing advisor, and to fund publicity campaigns in a variety of media, such as television, billboards, direct mail and the Internet.

We will also be able to expand our sponsorships of community organizations such as the Franklin Township Food Bank, the Franklin Township Animal Shelter, various sports-related and civic organizations and specific organizations' scholarships and programs.

We know from our experience, thus far, that when people discover the FR&A and what we offer, they are immediately supportive of it, want to be a part of it and want it to be a part of their daily lives.

In return for your contributions, we have a variety of perks lined up. Our gifts to you range from thank-yous on our site to branded merchandise, to a living-room Jazz concert by PJ Parker and her Jazz Trio. Please check out all the perks we are offering in the list to the right.

If we are not able to reach our goal, we will use whatever money is raised to fund smaller-level marketing campaigns.

What It All Means

We’ve been around for about a year and a half, and while we’ve achieved success in both subscriptions and advertising, it is important for us to enter the next level of awareness among our neighbors. Your support in this campaign will help us do that.

Local, independent news sites are the future of community journalism in our state and our country. Like us, the people who publish local news sites are passionate about their communities and want to make sure their neighbors know what’s going on around them. We know that an engaged citizenry can only lead to a more healthy democracy.

It is also important to understand that this is not just an appeal to Franklin residents; if we can show that we are successful, journalists in other towns and states throughout the country may also be emboldened to create online news sites for their communities. You could help usher in a Golden Age for community journalism!

Risks & Challenges

There are risks inherent in any business enterprise. The economy could downturn, which could result in obstacles for any business. Rest assured that we are very familiar with lemons and lemonade.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the resources to donate to a campaign like ours. But, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Please email your friends and co-workers and tell them about what we’re trying to do, and impress upon them the importance of independent, online news sites. Indiegogo has a number of sharing tools that you can use to get the word out.

We thank you for your belief in local, independent, hometown journalism, and thank you so much for your support!

story:
Oxenbury Personal Training Ltd.

My name is Dustin Oxenbury and I have been in the fitness industry for the last 3 years as a personal trainer/coach. Recently I have gone through a bit of a struggle at my current job as a trainer in the corporate world and now I am convinced to go out on my own terms. 

Each donation will help with my company purchase insurance and paying for any start up expenses upfront. 

I need to raise 2000.00 to get insurance/up front expenses.

Most of the funding will be contributed towards insurance:

-Insurance cost for 1 million liability minimum for 1 year is roughly 1200.00

-Registration for incorporating a business in canada/alberta is 250.00 

-Name search is 50-90.00

-NUANS search is 50-70.00 (to ensure legal documents of starting a small business in Canada/Alberta check out)

Equipment:

-Foam Rollers

-Bands

-10KG, 12KG, 16KG, 20KG KettleBells

My philosophy: (have not narrowed it down specifically yet however if I did it would be Health, Wellness, Fitness, Happiness, Caring and Living)

I got in the health industry to assist people in reaching their potential, to re-discover their purpose and to live their dreams. I know what its like to have your dreams ripped from underneath your feet, having a loved one taken away from you or losing that spot on your favourite sports team. Its not easy getting back up when you fall down however if you have the right tools to pull yourself back up you can handle anything that comes your way. Your toolbox is your body, your mind, your spirit, and your well-being. You need to know how to maintain a healthy you in order to move better, think better, feel better and live happier. Nothing will ever change until you decide its time, when you are sick and tired of being sick and tired. That is the time you will demand change not only for yourself but for your life, your dreams, your desires, your goals and your family.

story:
WHY ALPACA?

Alpaca fiber is one of the finest, most luxurious and prized fibers in the world. The fiber is soft, warm, light yet very warm, which makes it one of the most durable fibers. The hollow core of the fiber holds the warmth while at the same time providing freshness in warm temperatures.

Short Summary

We are Suritayka a women-owned company that sells Alpaca apparel from Bolivia. We are passionate about international development, particularly providing fair opportunities to women and disadvantaged people. We believe that our time in this earth is also to contribute positively to the lives of others. That is why we offer fair opportunities of growth to the entire chain of production of our company. 

With your help we will be able to launch our first collection in the US. At the moment we are working with Bolivian providers and artisans on a very small scale, however we got to a point where we need your contribution to take off the ground by making our first sales in the US.

What We Need & What You Get

We need 20,000 to launch a small collection and to have it ready on our website. 10,000 will go to cover the cost of acquiring the yarn. Alpaca being a luxury fiber has high prices. The other ten thousand will go from covering cost of production, that is fair price payments to small-scale artisans that will produce the garments, to the process and procedures that entail having the garments exported to the US, including export and import fees, and shipping costs and finally to cover a photo session for our website.

We are offering perks: scarfs, sweaters, shawls, ruanas and other of our products. We work with the best quality of Alpaca (Baby, Super-Fine and Royal). We are sure that if you try one of our products, you will know this cause is worth it and if you believe in our mission of giving fair opportunities to people in need, you will be proud to support this campaign.  

If we do not reach our goal, the donated funds will go to strengthen our company in Bolivia. That is, to continue very small scale production to be sold within the country or abroad by other means.  

The Impact

At the moment, Suritayka is supporting small scale artisans in Bolivia to grow to be independent while at the same time providing for their families. They work from small workshops in their homes. The role of women has been always in our minds -how hard it is and how little is recognized in many societies of the world. One of our objectives is to provide opportunities for women to earn income and we want to make it in a way that they stay close to their children at home. This entails increasing the number of female artisans working for Suritayka. Additionally, we want to reach disadvantaged communities of Alpaca herders in the Andes of Bolivia by buying their fiber at fair prices.

Risks & Challenges

 Our biggest challenge is to establish ourselves in key markets and our biggest risk is not to be able to find our place in those markets. However, we are tenacious, and persistent women -besides, honest and smart :)- we will not give up until we tried all the resources possible and knocked all doors possible.

With the age of cyber technology we live in, we have the resources to overcome both challenge and risk. The internet and pages such as  indiegogo are not just providing us with opportunities to fund our company but also to enter several different markets. With the high quality apparel that we produce we are sure that we will build loyal costumers that will provide Suritayka with strong presence in those markets. Additionally we count with organizations and even countries that can provide opportunities for women entrepreneurs.

Another of our risks is that artisans will not be loyal to the company after achieving relative independence. We plan to diminish this risk by maintaining our fair prices, giving respect and equal treatment to everybody we work with. There are other challenges, such as transportation of fiber and final products that can present themselves along the way but we are sure we can overcome any factor that poses a risk to this project.        

Other Ways You Can Help

Any help is needed, welcomed and appreciated, please spread the word using indiegogo share tools!

story:
As many of you know, I am the East Coast Regional Lead, and the CEO of Stage Motorsports, one of the Team Sponsors of Team NvUS World Wide. The Third Annual Gathering is happening in Cali, and I want to get out there to represent the East Coast. I have been out to California once in my life, for the filming of Furious 7, while out there, I made some amazing friends, that feel like family, and I really want to get out there to see everybody again, and to help set up and break down the event and help out in any way that I can. This would be an awesome experiance for me and would be a great step for the East Coast as well. 
We at Stage Motorsports, are wanting to make this worth your while, so we are going to be offering many perks to make this more attractive to you to help us on our journey to the West Coast. We are starting with lower donations as simple as decals, and working up to items being given to the buyer at cost pricing, which is an amazing way to save a ton of money and help get your build from where it is to the next level.
I also, really want to give Ryan Vanderhoof a big hug

story:
Happy 5th Birthday SurveyorConnect Community!  June 2010 - June 2015

It’s hard to believe that it has been 5 years already since the start of SurveyorConnect.com - The most active discussion forum in the World for surveyors. We’ve done a lot of listening regarding upgrades and feature requests for SurveyorConnect over the last 5+ years and there is still a lot to do as many people still don’t know about us yet. From 2010 we started with over 400 users and 5 years later we have almost 5000 users, average over 35,000 unique visitors/month and social media followers in the thousands.  

Barely scratching the surface - We need to expand the community

We have many plans to further protect and expand the current SurveyorConnect and we know that we are still not reaching everyone that could benefit from our great community. We know that to make SurveyorConnect exist for many years to come we need to stay relevant to all demographics including students, professionals and clients.

Past Investments and Looking Forward

We invest many hours of dedicated time to moderate, manage, maintain, upgrade and secure the website. This includes moderating posts, responding to email requests, helping new users get signed up, dealing with spam and hacker attacks, etc.

While we appreciate the generous donations and advertising support we’ve received in the past, it’s not enough to grow the SurveyorConnect community into the future. We have moved forward to address different geographic and demographic user requests, security improvements and technology upgrades in 2015 and now are looking at ways to market to and provide valuable content/services to the surveyor/geospatial worldwide community in 2016 and into the future.  

Worldwide Vision For The Future

Our growth far exceeded projections and we also have untapped potential in the surveying and geospatial markets.  The need to adapt - Whether you prefer the terms surveying, geospatial or geomatics professional, the conversations are happening worldwide with or without you. Our goal is to elevate the profession, not divide it.  We’re moving toward a worldwide approach for related geospatial professionals while still strongly supporting the surveying community.

ROI: What's In It For Me?

We’ve been able to implement most (if not all) of the reasonable features that have been requested by our users over the last 4 years by revamping the forum into a more mature and stable product, using software that was intended to handle larger communities. The new software we implemented with the future in mind, allowing us to grow into a mature, stable product that you can visit comfortably on your computer, tablet or smartphone.

Currently implemented in 2015:

Biz Card websites and Surveyor Directory http://plat.build/

Added features/Grid post on SurveyorConnect

Bernsten SurveyorConnect Monument map

Mobile App/Tapatalk (version 1)  - Android and iOS

Next Steps - Reasons for this round of funding (2016)

  1. Content

    1. We are looking for new ways to bring in more relevant, expanded industry related content while we expand our audience.  We are looking for partners, writers and industry experts to help and it takes time and resources to reach and connect with them

  2. Requested features/Testing

    1. Since we are still in the migration/beta testing phase for the new forum for the next two months (July - September 2015) we are evaluating all requests for adding features like nested comments to make your experience what you want it to be and also have many new ways and options to interact.  We are internally planning on rolling out features quarterly in 2016 which may include language support, blogging and other items.

  3. Global Marketing

    1. SurveyorConnect has been traditionally strong in the US Market with general emphasis on land and boundary surveying topics. We are actively looking for more ways to market to and connect communities, individuals, associations, technologies, education programs and industries within the larger global communities of geospatial, geo and various types of surveying.  

  4. Community Education and Support

    1. As we look for new ways to elevate the surveying and geospatial professions we are very focused around the people that make up these communities and the knowledge that can be shared across borders, professions and generations. We are looking for new ways to engage the communities regarding CEU/PDH courses and day to day FAQ’s as well

  5. Value Added Features/Services

    1. We can’t tell you all our plans here but we are looking at some simple value added services that could and should help you save money and even make more money in your business and we hope to start rolling these out toward the end of 2015

  6. Associations/Conference Support Attendance

    1. Even though we have almost 5000 registered users on SurveyorConnect we know that we are just scratching the surface to reach surveyor/geospatial professionals in the US and abroad and we are hoping to expand our reach by travelling to some major industry conferences in the coming years and need funds for travel expenses.  

Perk Concept Images

SurveyorConnect Sticker:

BeerLeg Definition Sticker:


Surveyor At Work T-Shirt (standard):


Surveyor At Work T-Shirt (5-Year Anniversary):


BeerLeg Definition T-Shirt:


SurveyorConnect / Berntsen Monument:

story: The money raised will be used for transportation of the toys and clothes I collected. My mother has been raising toys and clothes to send home for the past 20 years, and now I want to continue the tradition we have. Also, being a junior in High School, College applications are right around the corner, and I want to make a name for myself. Leading this campaign is a perfect way for me to do so. No donation is too small. Thank You

story:
One of the largest factors in someone making a healthy life transformation is community. An environment that encourages, educates and empowers will often be the difference between success and failure for people trying to overcome health issues and obesity. The Fuel Pump was dreamed up to be that difference. It will combine fitness, nutrition and a sense of community to help end the trend of obesity and support the public in making healthy changes for the whole family. 

The idea was born after a 2 hour Zumba-thon, as I watched people load up on double the amount of calories they'd just burned in soda and processed foods. All of that hard work wasted, because good food is rarely convenient food. I want to create a place where people can nourish there bodies and support their hard work. A studio gym, with various group fitness classes available, will be directly next door to a clean eating cafe where brunch is served all day long, with a priority on fresh, local, whole foods. 

Mom's, you're running errands want something to eat that will love you back but one child is sleeping and the other is a runner. Been there. The Fuel Pump wants to offer you curb side pick up just call in with your order and we'll run your baked oatmeal and hot latte right out to the car. Parents, your student excels when the body is properly nourished. We would be open late during Delmar HS mid-terms and finals to fuel your young world changers. Have a crazy schedule and missed class? Each day gym members will have access to the gym out of class hours for our workout of the day. To take care of others you must first take care of yourself, this is why all first responders will receive a discount at both the gym and cafe. The Fuel Pump wants to make living well totally doable for the entire community! Will you help us, help you? 

Risks and challenges

Restaurants are always a risk. There are so many factors consistency, service, quality a lot of which rest on the employees. As a member of the food service industry for several years I know that happy, appreciated employees make or break an establishment. We want the cafe to not only be a blessing to the customer but to the employees who work there. Continuing education, incentive programs, and recognition are a few ways we will make sure our employees feel like respected members of the team.

I know that this is a new concept so I am sure there will be hurdles that I have not even foreseen. I challenge myself every day in my fitness so that I am not afraid of a struggle. I believe this is what I'm called to do and with my vast network of experts and winners I surround myself with I am sure as a team we can solve any problem.

story:
My whole life, I've been a maker and a crafter.  It is in these moments I find myself happiest, most settled, and most serene - when I create and build.  

This funding will allow me to use that creativity to buy the machinery needed to start Stone Cabin Woodworks, LLC, creating Vermont themed and sourced souvenirs, ornaments, and mementos, for retail sale around Vermont and in my online store.

Stone Cabin Woodworks will be my own business, allowing me to work for myself, and most importantly, work from home.  We are planning to start a family, and it's very important for us to have a parent at home to take care of our future littles (not to forget our dog and two cats!).

Your help will change my life in such a positive way, allowing me to take care of my family, my home, and myself in a way I've always dreamed.

What I Need & What You Get

To break it down:

  • If I raise $3,000, I'll get a matching, no-interest, long-term loan from an amazing angel investor!  
  • My reach goal is $5,000 - that will get me fully up and running.
  • With these funds, I will buy needed machinery and tools and starting materials, and it'll cover overhead for a few months to get me rolling. 
  • What you get: custom wooden creations!  AND, the satisfaction of helping a small business get started!

The Impact

What difference will you make:

  • You'll support locally sourced American goods and the environment.  I'll be sourcing lumber from a family owned company, just a few miles from me, that sustainably harvests Vermont timber.
  • You'll allow Vermont business to buy Vermont made custom ornaments and souvenirs for sale in their stores.  
  • You'll support independent artists who create original designs. 
  • You'll help to launch a business and help me pursue my life-long dream of creating for a living!

Risks & Challenges

  • Ultimately, the risk is that people won't buy or won't buy enough.  This is why I'm prioritizing direct to business over individual sales.  The more of one item I can make, the more cost effective it is to produce and the more I can sell at once.  But, I have options, and with the machinery I'll purchase (a CNC machine - check out the gallery for videos of other CNCs at work) I'll be flexible to deal with whatever direction the market takes me.
  • The great thing about a CNC machine I'll purchase is that, if you can imagine it, I can make practically anything you want!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, or can't contribute much, I've been there, and I get it.  BUT, SHARING IS CARING! (E-mail your friends, or share on Facebook/Twitter!) That's one of the best things you can do to help me get funded!

story:
Craft beer revolution has reached the Western Balkans finally! Former homebrewers start new craft breweries throughout the countries of former Yugoslavia. Numerous gatherings of homebrewers and craft beer festivals take place frequently, joining many young people and destroying the boundaries placed by politics and war past and building new bridges of friendship and cooperation between nations.

Visits to several craft breweries in Croatia (Zmajska and Medvedgrad) and Serbia (Kabinet and Crow) gave me strong motivation and I finally decided to turn my hobby into something more serious and exciting - to open Highlander Craft Brewery at my late grandfather's farm in the village of Jakupovci, 16km from Banja Luka.  

What is craft beer?

Craft beer is made of all natural ingredients, without the addition of preservatives or artificial adjuncts. It is usually made by homebrewers and small local craft breweries. It comes in various styles and some of the most popular include American Pale Ale, India Pale Ale, Belgian Blond Ale, German Weizen, Amber Ale, Porter, and Stout. Craft beer is most often unpasteurized and unfiltered. Its high nutritive value and positive effects on health combine with the diversity of flavors and aromas, making it a true joy. 

In the brewery, I will be making several styles of beer like American Pale Ale, Blonde Ale, Brown Ale, Stout, Weizen, Abbey Ale and Gruit - a specialty ale with aromatic and medicinal herbs.

Why the countryside?

In the post-war Bosnia and Herzegovina, youth unemployment is over 60% (the highest in Europe), meaning that many young people cannot afford to start a family or travel and meet other people and areas of the world, and they rely on their parents even at the age of 30+.  At the same time, villages are being abandoned and many young people go to cities to look for jobs, but job offer is scarce. When faced with many disappointments, they finally leave the country. 

I wish to give an example to all young people that our countryside offers plenty of opportunity for having a happy and fulfilled life. I wish that my 12-year-old nephew living at the farm stays there and starts his own family someday, just like his friends. It is only through the development of the local economy that this and other villages can survive. And we must remember, it is the villages and farms that kept us going during hard times.   

My mission

Quality craft beer for all! My mission will be to promote creation and creativity on the example of craft brewery as the only way of moving forward. Your support will enable me to turn this hobby into a real business and to contribute to the growth of the emerging local craft beer scene.  

How?

I am in the process of making the brewhouse with currently available funds, but your donations will help me purchase the remaining equipment and convert an old country house into a brewery. So:

What do I offer to you?

- Highlander brewery T-shirts in two colors, male and female. Just state your size, preferred color, and gender when making a donation ;). 

- 4-packs and cases of Highlander craft beer delivered to your address (Bosnia and Herzegovina only)

- learn how to brew at your home

- spend 3 days in Banja Luka, enjoy its nature, try some traditional local food, experience rafting, swimming, and barbecue on the Vrbas River, learn more about the culture and history of this region, visit an ancient Roman fortress and medieval monasteries in the city countryside. And of course, drink all the craft beer you can. :) 

Timeline

Why do I think I can do it?

My whole life I've been multitasking - at work, in music, all the time. Through plenty of reading I have done and advising with professional brewers I have gained enough knowledge to run my own brewery with the beginning capacity of 1500 liters a month. Of course, I will always keep on learning more, because it is a process lasting for a whole life. Luckily, I have many friends in different branches, such as civil engineering, food production, economy, microbiology, graphic design, sales, and cafes and bars who support my idea. Also, at this moment, more than a hundred individuals from my surroundings have tried some of my beers and would like to have them available in their favorite bars and retail sale. My biggest support comes from my girlfriend Nina, who is helping me organize all campaign activities.

I am very enthusiastic and will do everything to make this idea succeed! 

The Impact

By supporting my campaign you will directly contribute to the development of the young and emerging craft beer scene in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the city of Banja Luka. 

I will do my best to promote the entrepreneurial way of thinking among young people by using this example. I will make sure to bring good quality craft beer to everyone!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a donation, but you'd like to support my campaign, let your friends know about it, use Indiegogo share tools, share and post information on social networks.

Spread the word! :) 

Thank you!

Nikola Galić & Nina Toljaga

Za verziju na srpskom jeziku kliknite ovdje.

story:
When we moved to Hawai'i I had to leave most of my supplies and inventory in storage. I'm in need of help with building my inventory back up, so I can re-open my online store.  

All of our money is going into our home we are building.

If you help me get my business going again I will send each of you a thank you gift! 

Anything helps gets me closer to my goal and get my shop open again.. Thank you if you can help :)

story:
First Off: 
Helpfulthreads.com is an apparel site motivated to help those in need by teaming up with charities and charitable organizations to provide funding and attention to those organizations.


Why We Need You:

We are looking for $700 to  file the necessary licensure and to provide future apparel to the site. 

In following with our missions statement, each shirt sold will directed benefit a cause. For this campaign, each shirt will provide a meal to a child in need in Zimbabwe through VisionTrust International. 

$19 Helpful Threads Feeder T-Shirt

$30 Helpful Threads Embroidered Beanie 

$50 Helpful Threads Feeder T-Shirt and Embroidered Beanie 

The Impact

Helpful Threads has the potential to help many people through these charitable organizations. We want to be able to team up with multiple organizations to spread their cause! With your contribution, you will directly help not just a single person in need, but many people to come. 



Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute, that's cool, we understand. If you can't help financially, help us get the word out! Follow, like, share, post anything with us!

www.helpfulthreads.com

www.facebook.com/helpfulthreads

Instagram: @helpfulthreads (www.instagram.com/helpfulthreads)

Twitter: @helpfulthreads (www.twitter.com/helpfulthreads)

story:
The Problem We Are Trying to Solve

Indian Education Sector is a $25 Billion Industry. 40% of India is below the age of 18. But even after such great potential, only 25% of Graduates in India are considered employable (Nasscom-McKinsey Report). Even after 16 years of rigorous education, graduates need to be trained from the very basic in Industrial skills. 
Moreover, students here do not get to choose their own career paths. Most of the knowledge imparted is theoretical and students are forced to cram and learn by rote.

There are 23 million eligible kids in India for education (Data for 2004), 83% of whom reach Grade 3 and only 34% reach grade 10 while just 2.3 million (10%) become graduates. 13 million kids drop out between grade 1 and grade 10! 
Half of this dropout numbers is due to distinct lack of interest in education and non-visible goals for a good future (which usually requires 15 years of rigorous education to achieve).

So we thought of introducing our flagship product - Gyan Labs (practical learning and value-added experimenting labs) at low resource government as well as private school and provide this facility absolutely FREE of COST. Gyan Labs has been tested and is proven to attract the attention of students through a model that provides hem with learning and fun components at the same time.


Our Story - About ADD-on-GYAN Educational Services (AOGES)

Hi, I am Priyadeep, Co-Founder & Managing Director of AOGES. And here is our story - AOGES's journey.

Based on the problems mentioned above we started AOGES with the aim to reduce the problems in the educational sector in India, to EMPOWER the students in India and to make them independent and choose their own career options. We began operations in January, 2011 to establish Gyan Labs for students of grades 6 - 9. We set out by establishing our Pilot Model of Gyan Labs at a school in Manipal, Karnataka (India) in June, 2011. In this lab, we provide students with the physical apparatus to conduct experiments along with a very specific user manual made to suit their level of understanding. We aim to provide 12 - 30 kits to a school based on the number of classes we conduct in a month which could be 1, 2 or 4 classes per month. So this is our basic operation. We are running our first Gyan Lab well and will bootstrap our resources into establishing more labs for other schools across India.

But, at present we wish to set up Community Gyan Labs for underprivileged schools in India as well but do not have the necessary monetary resources to implement the same.

Hence, we came to IndieGoGo looking for assistance in setting up the these community Gyan Labs.   

The Impact

If you choose to help us and we reach the target funds to be raised, we would be able to provide the GYAN LABS to around 1000 underprivileged school students and help them shape a better future for themselves. It would be a lifetime opportunity for these kids as they would never dream of getting such a facility for themselves. We would go to any end to see this happen even if we are unable to raise the funds here but the only problem would be that these labs would have to be postponed until the company is well off and is able to pay for and manage Community Gyan Labs which could take as long as 3 years from now. 

So your help could help us create the change at this very moment and help in the process of changing the flawed Indian Education System. 


What We Need & What You Get

Monetary Requirement Break-down of setting up Community Gyan Labs:

Apparatus and Equipments - $750

Box Cartons - $500

Manuals - $450

Workbook & Career Books - $650

Manufacturing and Misc Cost - $150 

Total Cost of establishing - $2500

Number of community labs to be established with total raised funds - 2

And even if we get 70% of the required monetary help needed, we would put in our money to create these community labs.


Unique Perks

$2500 - We will name one of the community Labs after you. Feature you as one of the sponsors of AOGES on the website with detailed write-up on you. Name and photo on all manuals, workbooks and careerbooks. Gyan Lab Mug.

$1000 - Your name and message on all the AOGES Kit Cartons for a specific lab. Your photo and name on AOGES website. Name and photo on all manuals, workbooks and careerbooks. Gyan Lab Mug.

$500 - Your name and message on all AOGES Kit Cartons for a specific grade. Your photo and name on AOGES website. Name and photo on all workbooks and careerbooks. Name on manuals too. Gyan Lab Mug.

$100 - Your photo and name on AOGES website. Name and photo on all workbooks and careerbooks. Name on manuals too. Gyan Lab Mug.

$50 - Your photo and name on AOGES website. Name and photo on all workbooks and careerbooks. Gyan Lab Mug.

$25 - Your name and photo on the AOGES Website and name on workbook and careerbooks.

$10 - Your name and photo on AOGES website.


Other Ways by Which You Can Help

Please help us by putting info about us, our work and our model on your facebook, twitter, myspace and other social networking pages. Please share our website and this page with as many acquaintances as you can in order to make this venture of ours successful.

story:
My Story

Hi, my name is Chris VanDusen and my dream since I was a kid is to own a bike shop. My love for bicycles started when I learned to ride one at age four. I was fascinated by how these human powered machines worked and began fixing my own bike when I was about eight years old. I was fortunate to get a job at the local bike shop as a mechanic at sixteen years old and worked my way up to manager by my early twenties. From there, I worked as both a tour guide, tour developer, and office manager for the bicycle touring company Classic Adventures. I currently manage the Bike Zone, a successful bike shop in Rochester, NY.

 

Here is an article that was written about me on crazyguyonabike.com. Click here to read it. It pretty much sums up my passion and commitment  to keeping cyclists rolling down the road and trail.

 

My goal is to open a bike shop located between Buffalo and Rochester, NY along side the historic Erie Canalway Trail. The Erie Canalway Trail is also part of a larger network of cycling routes across the US including the Northern Tier Bicycle Route from Adventure Cycling .  I plan to serve cyclists from my local community and those long distance bicycle touring. 

 

With your help, I'll be able to continue my passion for bicycling and serve as a resource for all traveling along the Erie Canalway Trail corridor.

The Impact

The Erie Canalway Trail is becoming a hot destination for all types of cyclists, from casual riders to fully loaded self contained bicycle tourists  The trail's popularity is increasing use every year.  Currently there is only one bike shop within the forty mile section of the trail where my shop will be located. The location along the trail gives riders easy access for bikes, rentals, repairs, parts, accessories, and refreshments. The store will also be the only bicycle repair shop in Orleans County, NY.

 

I will also offer bicycle repair clinics and a guided bicycle tour of the Erie Canalway Trail once a year.

 

What I Need & What You Get

 

In a nutshell, this is what I need to make this happen:

 

  • Make renovations
  • Purchase tools
  • Purchase Inventory
 
If I don't reach my goal, I will still honor all the perks to those who helped, including tune-ups and discounts. The only exception will be a minimum of three people pledging the guided tour of the Erie Canalway Trail.
 
That's right, for my $2000 pledges, I'm offering a fully supported, guided bicycle tour of the historic Erie Canalway Trail. This will be a 6 night/7 day tour from Buffalo to Albany. Lodging will be a mix of B&B and hotels, all meals except lunches are included.  Once you've finished the tour,  you'll be an Official Erie Canalway "End to Ender"
 
As I'm sure you've guessed, some of these perks are to be redeemed locally, so for those "out of towners", I hope you take advantage of my 25% off all merchandise for one year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Just getting the word out is a huge help and will be greatly appreciated. Please share on Facebook, blogs, email, or by word of mouth.  Thank you for your help!

story:
Our Story

Many of you know and love my friend Brad. And many of you know he suffered a stroke in November.


After some time in the hospital and in rehabilitation, Brad will be returning to his home this week. His family is down in Florida (from Kentucky) helping out while he recovers. (I might add that his recovery has been miraculous. Go Brad!)


If you're like me, my first impulse is to bring a casserole to my friends and neighbors in times like these. Cooking and preparing meals takes a lot of time, so that's why the gift of food is actually the gift of time spent with loved ones. We may not be as close in proximity as in times past, but there's no reason why we can't still help out.


Let's raise money to get dinner to his home for a few weeks while Brad's family is in Panama City helping out.  A week of meals for four is $137 from Spice of Life in Panama City (http://spiceoflifepc.com). Can you help me raise money for four weeks of meals to help out during this transition? Any little bit would be greatly appreciated.


Bless you and yours this holiday season!


What We Need & What You Get

We need a little cash to give Brad's family meal delivery for the next 4 weeks. You get the pleasure of knowing you helped out from far away.


Any money raised beyond our original goal will be given to the Morris family for whatever they need (Art supplies for Brad? Therapy copays? More meals? Whatever they need...)


Other Ways You Can Help

Brad's mom is posting regularly on his facebook page with updates and ideas on how you can send love and encouragement to Brad.

story:
As a Christian missionary in Honduras, I had the pleasure of teaching Isabel and getting to know her. We've remained in contact since.

Isabel is a caring individual and hard worker. She has since moved to the United States with her son, Daniel, and is trying to make ends meet.

She can get a job in the city near where she lives, but doing so requires transportation -- something she currently is not able to consistently rely upon.

She needs a car.

Nothing fancy, nothing with bells and whistles. Just a car that works.

So we're going to raise $900 for her -- enough to get a functioning car so she can keep a steady job and help support her family.

This isn't a lofty goal, but the need is great. Isabel is reaching the end of her rope and could really use a leg up. Having this car, and thus holding a job, would be a significant help.

Can you help?

story:
I see a need for professional, high quality, trustworthy pet services.  My name is Olga and ever since I was a little girl I have been connected to animals –adopting stray dogs and cats, caring for sick and injured animals, and truly appreciating the wonderful experience of connecting one on one with animals and learning from their wisdom.

Caring for Your Animals as if They Were My Own

I know this work is a great fit for my passion and skills. Like any smart entrepreneur I already know I like this work and am good at it!   I have been working as a contract pet sitter and am ready to launch and grow my own business.

I don't want others to go through the same frightening experience I had a couple of years ago. I hired a vet tech to provide overnight care for my dogs and cats.  I had a gut feeling that she wasn’t delivering the care I was paying her to provide.  I enlisted my neighbor, who retired from the FBI, in some detective work while I was out of town.  He reported that the pet sitter drove up to the house in the evening and went inside and then left 15 minutes later, not to return until morning for another short visit.  My gut was right; the pet sitter was lying to me and not staying overnight as she was hired to do.  Since I was concerned about my animals, I immediately hopped in the car and drove seven hours home. 

I’m starting a professional pet care business because I love animals, I’m trustworthy and I provide high quality services.   In addition to providing superb pet care, I am also focused on excellent customer service.  My clients feel secure when I care for their pets; they know I am dependable and some might even say I’m hyper-vigilant about watching over their companion animals (they love this oh-so-relevant characteristic of mine).

I will provide high quality services including daily dog walking, overnight care, daytime visits, and puppy training and visits.

How You Can Help

In order to successfully launch my professional pet care business and be ready to provide services during the high demand end of year holiday season I need to get some key business components in place now.  Your support will allow me to:

1. Join Pet Sitters International – and gain access to the industry’s largest array of services.

2.  Purchase an Insurance Policy designed specifically for professional pet sitters.

3.  Develop marketing materials including a logo, website, brochure and business cards.

If I exceed my funding goal then additional funds will be directed toward setting up core business operations with a laptop, pet scheduling software and smart phone to be able to access schedule, email, and client contacts all while working in the field.

Other Ways You Can Help

In additional to any financial support you can provide (gifts of all sizes are greatly appreciated!) please help by telling your friends and family about my funding efforts.  Please forward this link to your friends and post it on your Facebook page.  If you or someone you know can provide quality pro bono marketing design support, then please contact me ASAP.

Thank You Thank You Thank You

Every contribution is greatly appreciated. Knowing I have your support provides me with even more fuel and energy to launch my new business.  Thanks so much.

story:
Mother Jones Food Pantry

Mother Jones Food Pantry delivers meals to folks in the community who need it.  They had saved for 10 years for a large delivery truck (17' used Ryder/UHaul-type), and, after having it for all of 10 days (and before insuring it), a thief made off with it last Monday.  

What the Money Is Being Raised For

After a quick look around the internet, it appears that used 17' box trucks are being sold for around $5500.  I figured, with sales tax, registration, processing fees, and the like, that $7000 should cover the cost of a replacement.  Any little bit counts.  See the story here:  http://chicagoist.com/2012/06/21/today_in_awful...

I saw the success of some other charitable ventures (Karen the Bus Monitor) and thought I'd give it a shot.    

The Impact

Although Mother Jones continues to operate as it has before it had the truck (using the personal vehicles of the volunteers), the need for the larger delivery truck is growing as the economic conditions in the greater Chicago area remain bleak for many residents.  Even if we don't get enough here to buy a new truck, whatever money is gathered will go to Mother Jones to aid them in providing their essential service to the community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have money to give that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • If you live in the area, give your time to support the organizations helping those in the Chicago area in need.  
  • Tell your friends about this.  It is a truly tragic situation; maybe they'd be willing to give a few dollars to help get Mother Jones another truck.

Mother Jones Food Pantry delivers meals to folks in the community who need it.  They had saved for 10 years for a large delivery truck (17' used Ryder/UHaul-type), and, after having it for all of 10 days (and before insuring it), a thief made off with it last Monday.  
What the Money Is Being Raised For
After a quick look around the internet, it appears that used 17' box trucks are being sold for around $5500.  I figured, with sales tax, registration, processing fees, and the like, that $7000 should cover the cost of a replacement.  Any little bit counts.  See the story here:  http://chicagoist.com/2012/06/21/today_in_awful...


I saw the success of some other charitable ventures (Karen the Bus Monitor) and thought I'd give it a shot.    
The Impact
Although Mother Jones continues to operate as it has before it had the truck (using the personal vehicles of the volunteers), the need for the larger delivery truck is growing as the economic conditions in the greater Chicago area remain bleak for many residents.  Even if we don't get enough here to buy a new truck, whatever money is gathered will go to Mother Jones to aid them in providing their essential service to the community.


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you don't have money to give that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

If you live in the area, give your time to support the organizations helping those in the Chicago area in need.  
Tell your friends about this.  It is a truly tragic situation; maybe they'd be willing to give a few dollars to help get Mother Jones another truck.

story:
Short Summary

Johnson State College is a small school located in the hills of northern Vermont.  This April, we (thirteen students and three staff and community members) will travel to Detroit to volunteer and as part of an ongoing study of the city.  In collaboration with native Detroiters, we will donate our time to organizations that work to combat poverty and homelessness and build community.  Upon our return, we will present our experiences to the college and to the local community.  This trip will be 100% paid for by fundraising efforts. 

How it all began....
Every year, incoming students at JSC read a book that offers that class a common experience; the book is followed with programming that explores the book's themes. This year the book was Detroit: An American Autopsy by Charlie LeDuff.  The book generated a lot of enthusiasm around travel to the Motor City.  We hope to continue learning about the city and the issues it faces while simultaneously giving back.

What We Need

We need $5000 to cover our basic costs. 

Donations will fund:

-  Van travel from Vermont to Detroit

-  Meals, sleeping accommodations, and other living expenses for the duration of the trip

-  Donations to non-profit organizations that support the group’s volunteer efforts

The Impact

Many Johnson State College students are the first in their family to go pursue higher ed.  75% are eligible for financial aid.  Most are from Vermont and many have not had the opportunity to travel outside of New England.  This trip will allow us to: 

  • engage in a unique service-learning opportunity
  • make a direct difference around issues we learned about in Detroit: An American Autopsy
  • experience travel to an urban environment, a setting vastly different than VT
  • learn valuable skills playing integral roles setting up and carrying out the trip
  • report back to the college and broader community (bonus!: Dale Dorsey, an award-winning Detroit police officer, will join us in VT for this presentation)

JSC has a long track record of successful service-learning trips.  Students have traveled to destinations all over the country and internationally, consistently dedicating their time to fundraising, service, and educating their own communities upon return.

Where We Will Be Volunteering

- Detroit Police Department (https://www.detroitmi.gov/DepartmentsandAgencies/PoliceDepartment.aspx)

- Gleaners Community Food Bank 

(http://www.gcfb.org/)

- The Empowerment Plan

(http://www.empowermentplan.org/)

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone can contribute financially. If you'd still like to support our cause:

  • Help us get the word out and let others know about our trip
  • Share this campaign on Facebook and other social media platforms

    Join us!  On Wednesday, May 7th at 6:30pm in Bentley 207 on Johnson State College's campus in Johnson, VT for our post-trip presentation.  https://events.jsc.edu/mastercalendar/MasterCalendar.aspx

story:
Just as the flutter of a Butterfly's wings has the potential to eventually cause a hurricane on the other side of the world, so too do your actions have a significant reaction! Every single thing you do matters! Changing just ONE thing can change EVERY thing! YOU HAVE WITHIN YOU THE POWER TO CHANGE THE LIFE OF A CHILD

Child Trafficking, specifically Child Sex Trafficking, is an epidemic that society has little to no real understanding of. This is a HUGE multibillion dollar business that uses a wide variety of techniques ranging from clever seduction to the MOST inhumane forms of torture imaginable, all with a common goal - to ENSLAVE their victims; often by simply providing the fundamental needs of the child - food, shelter and a very distorted sense of love and security. There is absolutely no doubt that these children, who have been tortured both physically and mentally, are VICTIMS in need of serious help and proper care.

Despite this urgent NEED, these children, more often than not, are treated as criminals and are subjected to prison time rather than rehabilitation and restoration. To make matters worse there are only around a SHOCKING one hundred beds available for these children in America, resulting in a massive shortage, and thus adding to the problem.

Please understand that this is not a "foreign problem" contrary to popular belief. The United States has an estimated 100,000-300,000 potential victims EVERY year and it affects ALL social classes (*for more staggering statistics, please visit www.RedefiningRefuge.org)

Redefining Refuge is dedicated to fighting for women and children who have been victims of the depraved injustice of sexual abuse, with a prevailing emphasis on the abolition of the domestic sex trafficking of minors. Through strong community alliances and public awareness education, we strive to replace devastation with restoration, oppression with freedom, and despair with great hopefulness. For us, this means far more than assisting with the provision of fundamental needs, but rather equipping and empowering these individuals to build strong foundations for their futures by creating real and lasting change by means of a specialized Housing and Rehabilitation Program.

Domestic Minor Sex Trafficking is nothing less than Modern Day Slavery, and just one child, is one child too many!

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

As Fall approaches, we are getting ready to open our very first Safe House here in the Tampa Bay area, and as you can imagine we are THRILLED! But along with all the excitement and anticipation of such a huge undertaking, comes more financial responsibility! That said, we'd like to raise enough funds to cover our monthly house payment ($1200) for the first 6 months ($7200) in addition to the utilities, rounding our goal off to $10,000. Please know that 100% of the proceeds will go toward the home and that ALL donations are tax deductible. (To Donate Now, scroll to the top right hand corner)

THE IMPACT

YOU will be changing the life of a child!!! YOU will be giving them a second chance! YOU will be helping us teach them that they DO NOT have to be a statistic of their experience!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread Awareness about our Cause! This is vital for CHANGE to occur!

We will always be in need of items like toiletries, towels, new clothing etc! Host an event for us at your place of business or school. Remember, nothing is ever too small to make a difference.

story:
"Of all public figures and benefactors of mankind, no one is loved by history more than the literary patron." - Payne's "Ode to Gaius Maecenas"

Promote Culture, Help CulturalBook Stay Online and Grow and We Will Succeed Together...

 

CulturalBook.com is one year old, and the beta-testing period is finally over.  Today, the site looks great and we have a slowly-growing membership of 3,350—among them: readers, writers, publishers, teachers, translators, scholars, students, people from all over the world.  The members are happy, and we’re happy; but we badly need to grow in order to keep the website running.   If we fail to accelerate the business this autumn 2012, we may have to close the site down.  When the membership is large enough, (we estimate 20,000), it will continue to grow on its own, exponentially and organically.  Until that time we wish to spend $1,500/month on marketing efforts to grow at a rate of 2,000-3,000 new members each month.

 

CulturalBook is currently not making income, and we stay (barely) alive thanks to small donations from members who love the site and believe in its future success.  We stand firm against putting commercial advertising on the site.  Much like a library, CulturalBook is a literary environment where members’ minds should be free of forced-distractions.  It would be an insult to them to sell their peace of mind (or personal information) to advertisers.  Our solution is to offer membership incentives (honorary and active “chairs”) through crowdsourcing as a means to keeping the site running and increasing the membership. 

 

In addition to the $1,500 marketing budget, we have to pay approximately $4,500/month to cover costs, including hosting fees, contractor and staff wages.  The wages are “bread without butter” considering we have four people on payroll.

 

If we raise $6,000 this month, we believe we can hit the 6,000 member-mark at the end of the month, (and, what is more important to current members, we can keep the lights on). Patrons of $50 and more will be rewarded with lifetime memberships to CulturalBook, as well as honorary titles.  These “ennobled” members will periodically enjoy special invitations and opportunities communicated to them by the founders of CulturalBook. 

 

  • Donation incentives start at $15.
  • $50 earns a lifetime CulturalBook membership with honorable "patron status" on a permanent page on the site. Your name or profile (according to your wishes) will also appear in our list of "honored CulturalBook patrons" in an article published on the homepage of our cultural magazine, CityRoom.com. The article will stay on the site with a permalink and be indexed by search engines.
  • $100 donations earn a lifetime chair in the “House of Patrons” (a club within the social site, visible to all members).  You will also be awarded site “moderator” privileges. Also, your name or profile will be published (according to your wishes) in a CityRoom.com article.
  • $500 donations earn a chair on the “Board of Advisers” with which you will be awarded voting rights and other privileges.  Your chairperson status will be publicized (optional) in press-releases and on CityRoom.com.  Patrons with board-member status will be authorized to vote on company decisions, thereby helping to shape CulturalBook into the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you cannot help financially, you can still receive an incentive for...

  • Inviting your address book join CulturalBook.com
  • Volunteering to help with our fundraising campaign

...please email staff@culturalbook.com to tell us how you would like to help.

story:
OUR STORY:

Maria Pitallano and I, Erin Fong, are industrial designers who teamed up in
our last year at California College of the Arts to design two products to help
those with food allergies. Throughout this project, we heard many stories of
how food allergies affected people physically, socially, and mentally, including
how children have cried because they could not eat the provided food due to
a nut allergy and how a woman was too afraid to use an epinephrine injector
on her friend even though he was going into anaphylaxis. These stories made
us realize how terrifying food allergies are and how it is a fear that people
should not have to live with.

My partner, Maria, was already aware of the dangers of food allergies, being a
mom who has to take every precaution with what her daughter eats because
she has several food allergies. However, in the Summer of 2011, Maria's 4
year old daughter ingested a food normally thought to be safe, that happened
to have a cashew puree ingredient. Her daughter spent 3 days in the pediatric
ICU. Despite all of the work she had done with Erin on this subject, and fully
aware of the importance of administering an Epipen immediately, she was
still too afraid to inject her daughter. Instead, she took the risk of getting her
daughter to the emergency room on time.

OUR GOAL:
After spending a year developing these products, we have received many
email messages from people, sharing their troubling stories with us and
desiring a better solution for themselves, family, and friends. Having an
allergic reaction can happen at anytime and anywhere, so our goal is
to give people a peace of mind that regardless of where they are, they
will be confident that the epinephrine needed to treat anaphylaxis is not
only available to them, but that they can intuitively, confidently and easily
administer it. We plan on achieving this goal with our two injectors that will
together cover both public and private locations.

PRODUCT DETAILS:
Epi Inject is a new type of treatment delivery system for people who have food
allergies and received the Spark International Concept Design Award.

The Epipen, one of the only treatments currently available for allergic
reactions, has proven to save lives by administering the epinephrine that
will reverse the symptoms of an allergy attack. Because death can happen
in 10 minutes, epinephrine gives the person enough time to wait for the
paradmedics to arrive. However, an astonishing number of people with food
allergies refuse to carry it because of its bulky size, the stigma attached to
carrying a medical device, and the fear of having to stab themselves with a
needle.



Epi Inject for Personal Use: At 2" x 3", it is small enough to fit in your back
pocket or can be secured to your bag.


Epi Inject for Public Use: We want this to be as ubiquitous as defibrillators
at gyms and airports. To be installed in schools, parks, or restaurants, the
Epi Inject for public spaces is designed for quick and easy administration by
anyone.


Both injectors use a spring loaded trigger, eliminating the need to use physical
force to inject the epinephrine.

WHAT IS NEEDED:
Because medical devices can be tricky to develop, we are hoping to partner
with a pharmaceutical company to further develop it and produce it. In order
to present this to a company, we need to take the responsibility of patenting
these two products. Therefore, the $7000 we are requesting will pay for the
patent for each injector. Any additional funds will help us to produce working
prototypes.

PERKS:
While we cannot give out the actual Epi Inject product, we would love to show our gratitude by sending you a personal note, sharing our hand drawn cartoons with you, or giving you an embroided iron on patch designed with our Epi Inject logo.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:
1. What's your story? Share it with us by clicking on the comment tab.
2. Posting on facebook and forwarding this information to family and friends.
3. We're always trying to connect with people! Let us know if you know of
any professionals in the medical field who can help us make connections to
pharmaceutical companies.

story:
Short Summary

Brannon Thomas, "Z" has been battling brain tumors for most of his adult life.  My amazing and brave cousin and his family appreciate your support.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The goal is for $1500 to cover the costs associated with my Aunt Gail (who supports her family) to miss work so that she can be with Brannon in the hospital while the doctor's work to figure out how to properly balance the medications and the seizures.  Brannon is scheduled to start chemotherapy again in two weeks.

The Impact

  • Our combined efforts and donations (every dollar counts) will allow Brannon to have the support of his mother by his side during a critical time.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word and send thoughts of love.  Thank you so much!

Please spread the word and send thoughts of love.  Thank you so much!

story:
My name is Barbara Vagliano and I am an artist based in New York City.  In 2009 Peter Jones, a British ornithologist and I delivered nature education materials to AHTD (Association HAy Toumour du Development), a very active community center in the town of Zagora in the Moroccan desert. This project was also supported by New York Audubon´s For the Birds program.  A person affiliated with BirdLife International translated our field guide of desert birds into Moroccan Arabic.
 
I was so impressed with the successful positivity of AHTD that I helped them to set up a website where you can see all the activities they provide for their community in Zagora: ahtdzagora.org.  These activities include literacy for women, sewing of traditional crafts, diabetes diagnosis, sports, daycare and afterschool care.  The community center is led by Mbarek Bousekkine , a dynamic and impressive community leader. 

I am supporting this urgent campaign for them to raise $2500 in this coming week so that they will be eligible for a grant from the Initiative Nationale pour le Developpement Humain.  If they raise the full amount the regional organization will put in the equivalent of $5 for every $2 that they raise.  They have raised half the money they need but need your help to reach their goal.
 
This grant will provide AHTD with access to a much needed room where the children can have access to the internet and a room for the women to create  traditional handicrafts.  This will make a big difference to their lives and is one more step in the development of a  community center with a proven track record.  If you go on their website you will see that the Governor of the region is supporting them as well.

Please help me to help ADHT in this action for positive change.   The funds I receive on Indiegogo will go into my bank account and I will wire transfer them to Mbarek Bousekine in whom I have a lot of confidence.  In fact we will be returning to Zagora in April 2013 to convince Mbarek to apply for an Ashoka grant and to help him to find a permanent home for the community center.  That is why you will be receiving your perks in April 2013.

The conversion rate on the 14000  Moroccan Dirhams that they need was $2335 USD on October 13, 2012. Once Indiegogo has taken its commission this is the amount that will be available for them to reach their goal.

If AHTD does not get to their goal, the money will go for much-needed school supplies for the children. But with your help they will reach this goal for which they have raised half the funds.

Many thanks for your support.

My name is Barbara Vagliano and I am an artist based in New York City.  In 2009 Peter Jones, a British ornithologist and I delivered nature education materials to AHTD (Association HAy Toumour du Development), a very active community center in the town of Zagora in the Moroccan desert. This project was also supported by New York Audubon´s For the Birds program.  A person affiliated with BirdLife International translated our field guide of desert birds into Moroccan Arabic. 
I was so impressed with the successful positivity of AHTD that I helped them to set up a website where you can see all the activities they provide for their community in Zagora: ahtdzagora.org.  These activities include literacy for women, sewing of traditional crafts, diabetes diagnosis, sports, daycare and afterschool care.  The community center is led by Mbarek Bousekkine , a dynamic and impressive community leader. 

I am supporting this urgent campaign for them to raise $2500 in this coming week so that they will be eligible for a grant from the Initiative Nationale pour le Developpement Humain.  If they raise the full amount the regional organization will put in the equivalent of $5 for every $2 that they raise.  They have raised half the money they need but need your help to reach their goal.
 
This grant will provide AHTD with access to a much needed room where the children can have access to the internet and a room for the women to create  traditional handicrafts.  This will make a big difference to their lives and is one more step in the development of a  community center with a proven track record.  If you go on their website you will see that the Governor of the region is supporting them as well.Please help me to help ADHT in this action for positive change.   The funds I receive on Indiegogo will go into my bank account and I will wire transfer them to Mbarek Bousekine in whom I have a lot of confidence.  In fact we will be returning to Zagora in April 2013 to convince Mbarek to apply for an Ashoka grant and to help him to find a permanent home for the community center.  That is why you will be receiving your perks in April 2013. The conversion rate on the 14000  Moroccan Dirhams that they need was $2335 USD on October 13, 2012. Once Indiegogo has taken its commission this is the amount that will be available for them to reach their goal. If AHTD does not get to their goal, the money will go for much-needed school supplies for the children. But with your help they will reach this goal for which they have raised half the funds. Many thanks for your support.

story:
Angry Golfers LLC is a new company that has been in business for just over a year.  We are a small company of 3 that love golf and want to support golf throughout the world.  We know how frustrating golf can be and by expressing it through apparel and accessories have found that players become aware of their anger and become less angry when others around them say "Angry Golf". 

We sell polo shirts, golf balls, hats, visors, ball markers, beer koozies, power car decals, towels, key chains, divot tools, hoodies, headbands, coffee cups and pens.

We also have branched into Angry Bowling and Angry Gambling and soon Angry Soccer brands, with primarily shirts and sweatshirts.

We are looking for funding to allow us to upgrade to a new digital printer to allow us to lower our cost, expand our inventory, expand our brands and reach new customers.

If we cannot reach our goal, we will use any proceeds to sponsor golf and bowling tournaments as well as teams and foursomes.

Thank you for your assistance!

story:
The Terrazas Community Kitchen Project

My name is Lynda Haliburton; I am participating in a 6 month program at Santa Clara University, through the Leavey School of Business.  The program, Women Leaders for the World, is part of the Global Women Leaders Network that provides training to women in the areas of leadership, networking principles and strategies.

I currently work for City Team International as a Teaching Assistant. While on vacation in 2010, I went on a mission’s trip to Terrazas, a colony in Tijuana, Mexico. My life was impacted by what I saw: people living on hillsides in cardboard and tin housing with no running water or electricity, and children who had never owned a new toy or eaten a hamburger. The “kitchen” that serves the community is currently a concrete platform, that’s it!  The community leaders brought equipment such as bar b q pits, tables, bottled water to wash serving hands, and utensils from other areas to cook and serve meals to hungry families then pack up everything after the people were fed. 

Since then, helping the community of Terrazas complete the kitchen has been one of my goals. With business and community leaders' support, we’ve procured an industrial oven, 200 brand new chairs and leadership training for men, women and children.  Your support will help develop this community kitchen. The site will be used for multiple purposes: free meals, trainings and classes.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to reach our goal to raise $9, 200 to purchase items such as support beams, flooring, sheet rock, windows, electrical and plumbing supplies, tools, materials for the roof and labor. ALL FUNDS donated whether large or small will be used to complete the kitchen.

To show our appreciation, we have created a few perks for your generosity:

$5 – A personal thank you note.

$10 – A Power of One wristband and shout-out on our Facebook page.

$25 – A personal thank letter with a photo of the community and a shout-out on our Facebook page.

$35 – A gift certificate to the DevineGrind Coffee House in San Jose, Ca.

$50 – A gift certificate to the House of Soul Food in San Jose, Ca.

$100 – Your name will be placed on a quilt block on the Terrazas Community Quilt.

$500 – You are invited to come with us on our next trip to Terrazas and meet the people and see the kitchen site.  

The Impact

We are teaching people how to fish not just giving them a handout.  The kitchen will
serve as a focal point in the community to provide food for hungry families and
provide a space for trainings in social and economical development.

Other Ways You Can Help

Helping to get out the word about this project is essential to achieving our goal. If you can't make a donation at this time there are still ways you can help make a difference.

1. Share our link on your Faceback page.

2. Twit about our project on your Twitter account.

3. Tell your friends, family and co-workers about our fundraiser.

4. Help us get the word out to other organizations about our efforts to build a kitchen and community center.

If you are not comfortable with making an online donation please feel free to send a check or money order to:

Maranatha Outreach Center - Terrezas Kitchen Project

1811 S 7th St. Suite D

San Jose Ca. 95112

Thank you in advance for your trust and support.
